citations.narrative:
Early morning (i.e. 2:39am) on November 26, 2024, an intruder had 17 minutes of unauthorized access to the facility and
missed encountering the security officer by 56 seconds during security walking rounds. Video surveillance showed the
intruder was able to hoist himself over a solid vertical 8-foot panel perimeter fence and solid concrete 10-foot pillar at the
main gate by utilizing the perpendicular hand railing that is connected to the main gate concrete pillar. The intruder
proceeded to the outdoor dolphin habitat and jumped over the 3.5-foot public barrier consisting of top and bottom
horizontal beams connected via vertically spaced posts. While inside the public barrier the intruder picked up three large
8-9 inch diameter rocks from the surrounding landscape approximately 4 feet away from the pool enclosure and threw
them at the four dolphins housed in the enclosure. The dolphin team found the rocks in the dolphin pool during their 7am
morning rounds which was approximately 4.5 hours after the intruder left the facility. The dolphins voluntarily retrieved the
rocks, gave them to trainers, and the dolphins stationed and ate normally. Veterinary examination of all four dolphins
included visual and behavioral assessments as well as ultrasounds which did not reveal evidence of shadowing that could
indicate ingestion of a rock foreign body.
Perimeter fencing that does not prevent animals and unauthorized persons from having contact with the marine mammals
can pose a safety risk which may result in injury or disease transmission to the marine mammals. Prior to the January 6,
2025 inspection, security monitoring improvements to the surrounding dolphin habitat area had been completed and
supplies for planned modifications to the perimeter fence were on order.
Correct by January 31, 2025 by ensuring the perimeter fence protects marine mammals by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from having direct contact with marine mammals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.103(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Early morning (i.e. 2:39am) on November 26, 2024, an intruder had 17 minutes of unauthorized access to the facility and 
missed encountering the security officer by 56 seconds during security walking rounds. Video surveillance showed the 
intruder was able to hoist himself over a solid vertical 8-foot panel perimeter fence and solid concrete 10-foot pillar at the 
main gate by utilizing the perpendicular hand railing that is connected to the main gate concrete pillar. The intruder 
proceeded to the outdoor dolphin habitat and jumped over the 3.5-foot public barrier consisting of top and bottom 
horizontal beams connected via vertically spaced posts. While inside the public barrier the intruder picked up three large 
8-9 inch diameter rocks from the surrounding landscape approximately 4 feet away from the pool enclosure and threw 
them at the four dolphins housed in the enclosure. The dolphin team found the rocks in the dolphin pool during their 7am 
morning rounds which was approximately 4.5 hours after the intruder left the facility. The dolphins voluntarily retrieved the 
rocks, gave them to trainers, and the dolphins stationed and ate normally. Veterinary examination of all four dolphins 
included visual and behavioral assessments as well as ultrasounds which did not reveal evidence of shadowing that could 
indicate ingestion of a rock foreign body.  
 
Perimeter fencing that does not prevent animals and unauthorized persons from having contact with the marine mammals 
can pose a safety risk which may result in injury or disease transmission to the marine mammals. Prior to the January 6, 
2025 inspection, security monitoring improvements to the surrounding dolphin habitat area had been completed and 
supplies for planned modifications to the perimeter fence were on order.  
 
Correct by January 31, 2025 by ensuring the perimeter fence protects marine mammals by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from having direct contact with marine mammals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

species.common: ASIAN EMERALD DOVE / GREY-CAPPED EMERALD DOVE
